summary: bats represent approximately one-fifth of 5,676 recognized species of mammals. rabies virus and related lyssaviruses, henipaviruses, filoviruses, and coronaviruses cause severe acute respiratory syndrome (4, 8, 15, 25, 28). study of more than 2,000 mammals, principally small rodents, in Trinidad failed to provide serological evidence of infection with TCRV. this is unusual in that all other arenaviruses with known hosts are rodent borne (12, 16) previous experimental infections of rodents in the 1970s and 1980s found that TCRV was lethal to newborn mice, causing paralysis and necrosis in the central nervous system. the bat colony has neotropical fruit bats of two species, Carollia perspicillata and A. jamaicensis. they are maintained together in a 36-m3 room that allows unrestrained free flight. the colony has been closed for 16 years and is rabies virus free. the titer of virus stock was 107 50% tissue culture infective doses (TCID50) per ml of BA1 medium (MEM, 1% bovine serum albumin, 350 mg/liter sodium bicarbonate, 50 ml/liter 1 M Tris [pH 7.6], 5 mg/liter phenol red) for the initial experiment, each of 12 male bats were inoculated with 100 l containing 106 TCID50 subcutaneously (s.c. sterile PBS i.n. group 3 consisted of two bats that received 106 TCID50 s.c. in the abdomen and one that received sterile PBS s.c. in its abdominal wall. the fourth group consisted of two bats that received 104 TCID50 s.c. in the abdomen and one that received sterile PBS s.c. in its abdominal wall. l of blood was collected from each bat each time and placed into 200 l of BA1 medium containing 5% FBS. serum samples were used for virus isolation attempts and neutralizing-antibody tests. RNA from oral swabs, rectal swabs, and organ samples was reverse transcribed using qScript cDNA synthesis kits. amplification was performed using 35 cycles of 94°C for 30 s, annealing at 56°C for 30 s, and extension at 72°C for 1 min. plasmids were purified using a QIAprep spin miniprep kit (Qiagen) the plasmids were then incubated at 37°C overnight in 4 ml of LB broth. the cells were kept at 37°C and 5% CO2 for 7 days. terminal serum samples from each bat were screened for anti-TCRV neutralizing antibody and by immunofluorescence. a log2 dilution series was prepared for each sample without the addition of serum to serve as an anti-TCRV positive control. l containing 4 105 Vero E6 cells was added to each well. the cells were incubated at 37°C and 5% CO2 for 7 days. the cells were then screened for the presence of TCRV. each infection experiment, bats were placed three to a cage in four cages. water was made available in bowls inside each cage, and individual bats were identified using numbered wing tags. group 1 consisted of two bats that received 106 TCID50 i.n. and one bat that received sterile phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) i.n. group 3 consisted of two bats that received 106 TCID50 i.n. and one bat that received sterile PBS i.n. swabs were collected from each bat every 2 days to test for virus shedding. the oral and rectal swabs were collected in 500 l of BA1 medium containing 5% FBS. the samples were then frozen at 80°C until they were processed. RNA was extracted from bat organ samples collected in RNAlater stabilization reagent (Qiagen, Valencia, CA) the organ samples were placed in 1.5-ml screw-cap tubes, and approximately 12 2.3-mm zirconia/silica beads were added to each tube. RNA samples were frozen at 80°C until they were used for reverse transcription.
